III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code Financial stability.
Title
Rule Code & CPA Rule 400.12203
Section (1) An agency shall demonstrate sufficient financing, on an ongoing
Description basis, to ensure the agency is carrying out its programs and meeting
the requirements for licensing. A plan of financing must include all
the following:
(a) A listing of all income sources and the anticipated amount of
income for the current fiscal year.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation There is a concern with the agency's finances.
Investigation Complaint document review and Interviews:
On 12/2/2024 this complaint was assigned to me, and I reviewed the
complaint by way of a Michigan Department of Health and Human
Services (MDHHS) Compliance Monitoring Memo. The memo dated
11/22/2024 indicated the agency’s audit report for the fiscal year that
ended 12/31/2023 had information within it that should be brought to
the DCWL’s (Division of Child Welfare Licensing) attention. The
memo noted sections from the agency’s independent audit as
outlined below:
Decline in Total Net Assets
Net assets indicate the extent to which revenues exceed expenses
and is an indicator of the financial health of an organization.
• The Agency has an increase in net assets of 0.14%, a positive
$1,580. A total net deficit of $1,431,307. Prior year net assets
as adjusted declined $1,432,493.
Working Capital
Working capital is a common measure of an agency’s liquidity.
Negative working capital generally indicates an agency’s inability to
pay off its short-term liabilities if they came due immediately.
2

• The agency’s working capital is a negative $75,980
• Prior year working capital was a negative $346,258.
Current Ratio
Current ratio tests liquidity by deriving the proportion of current
assets available to cover current liabilities. The higher the current
ratio, the more capable the agency is of paying its obligations. A ratio
under 1 suggests that the agency could be unable to pay off its
obligations if they came due at that point.
• The agency’s current ratio is 0.55:1
Limited Cash
This area noted:
• Although the Agency has historically operated with a high
cash balance, the agency currently has no cash balance.
• The lack of cash or cash equivalents suggests the agency
could be unable to meet current day-to-day needs.
• Long-term liabilities now, and referenced notes payable to
MDHHS for $265,013, U.S. Small Business Administration
(SBA) for $145,163 and Payroll taxes due the IRS for
$951,607. A total of $1,361,783.
• Going Concerns Issue Arising from Deficit in Net Assets:
➢ In the memo it indicated the agency has a deficit in net
assets in the amount of $1,431,307. Its current
liabilities exceed its current assets in the amount of
$87,016(Accounts Receivable, $82,522 minus current
liabilities, $169,538 = $87,016), as of December 31,
2023.
➢ The organization had a deficit in net assets in the
amount of $1,431,307 as of 12/31/2023. That its
current liabilities exceeded its current assets in the
amount of $87,010 as of 12/31/2023. These factors
raise substantial doubt about the organization’s ability
to continue as a going concern. The agency will
increase its revenue by providing additional services to
MDHHS; and management believes these factors will
contribute towards maintaining profitability.
• Availability and Liquidity-
➢ The availability funds are all Accounts receivable,
$82,522. The Agency has no cash. At December
31,2023, the monthly operating expenses were
$94,657.
➢ Homes for Black Children’s (HBC) financial assets as
of 12/31/2023 was $82,522. The agency’s monthly
operating expenses were $94,657 and at the end of
3

12/31/2023 the agency had $82,522 available to meet
expenditures in year ended 12/31/2024.
Interviews:
Senior Auditor:
On 1/13/2025 via email, I inquired of Senior Auditor of the
Compliance Monitoring Unit where the $265,013.00 mentioned in the
Memo as an amount reportedly owed by the agency to MDHHS
originated from. He indicated it was mentioned in the report for
FY2022, Note E. The overpayments mentioned in the FY2022 report
were new to him and this could have been from a review beyond his
scope. He indicated his department files do not have the information
regarding that amount.
Chief Administrator:
I spoke with and interviewed Chief Administrator (CA) about the
allegation by telephone on 12/2/2024; onsite on 12/5/2024,
12/19/2024 and 1/9/2025. I also received email statements and or
documentation from her or the agency on 12/5/2024,1/13/2025 and
1/14/2025.
CA reported she could understand the department having a concern
that the agency’s 2023 financial audit showed the agency having a
no cash balance/no accessible funds available, at that time. She
reported that is not their current situation. She reported as of
12/5/2024 the agency has a cash balance of $141, 800. 87, which is
via First Independent Bank. She reported that after the agency was
placed on the first provisional license the agency went six months
without an intake which amounted to a $150,000 loss for the agency.
Additionally, childcare payments of $46,949.62 that was due to the
agency from the department on December 28, 2023, had not been
received until January 2, 2024. This contributed to the 2023 financial
audit showing no cash balance for the agency at that time.
CA reported the agency being in a better financial position than it
was at the end of the financial audit in 2022 with respect to the
agency having a deficit of $85,016. She reported the agency did not
have a deficit in 2023 but had a $ 1,580 net asset. She expressed
concern about the toll and negative impact this matter has on staff
morale and reported the last special investigation outcome brought
about a loss of some long-term foster parents. She stated the
agency has done everything that was required of it, inclusive of hiring
a different financial auditor and creating a specialty committee. She
believes the agency has made progress since 2022 and 2023. She
reported the 2024 independent financial audit, which will not come
4

out until after September of 2025, will show the agency gaining
greater financial standing.
CA reported during the agency’s exit conference related to its last
renewal inspection, where the second provisional license was
recommended and subsequently issued, the agency’s
deficits/financial matters were not ones that would be eliminated in
six months. She hopes the department will take into account the
efforts they are making, the fact they continue to provide needed
services to children, and that they are increasing their number of
children served. Therein, creating additional revenue to continue
paying their debtors timely. She reported the agency currently
receives funding of approximately $46,000 bi-weekly for 38 children;
in addition to adoption income (which was $67, 750 in the prior fiscal
year). She reported these funding sources are indicated in the
independent financial audit.
She reported the agency is current with its foster care payments to
caregivers, its lease, utilities, IRS tax payments, over payments
owed the state, which they have confirmed, and other agency
financial obligations. She reported with respect to the old reported
high amount owed MDHHS (Michigan Department of Health and
Human Services), the agency attempted to verify any amounts owed
to the State for resolution over the past couple of years and they
addressed it in their past renewal corrective action plan related to
financial instability. She reported Financial Clerk also made recent
attempts to verify any amounts owed to the State. She reported with
respect to the SBA loan, the original amount of the loan was
$150,000, and as of August 7, 2024, the balance was $140,204. She
reported payments for this loan had been deferred by SBA; and they
resumed in May 2024. She reported the agency pays $641.00
monthly on this debt. The agency made a double payment in July
2025, for the June and July 2025 payment.
Financial Clerk:
On 12/19/2024, I interviewed Financial Clerk onsite. She reported
her role is to ensure payrolls are dispensed and the agency bills are
paid. She reported there have been no late payments to foster
parents, relative caregivers, staff or other entities or debtors.
She reported making inquiries, mostly via telephone and some faxes,
to the State in an attempt to find out what, if any monies the agency
may owe MDHHS. These inquiries were from June 2024 through
August 2024, and mostly with the Bureau of Finance and
Accounting. She reported not having a specific MDHHS staff
person’s name. She reported the parties she had contact with
5

ultimately indicated via a letter dated 10/10/2024 that the agency
only owed $742.31, for a past over payment; and HBC made that
payment to MDHHS in October 2024.
Agency Employees
On 12/20/2024 I interviewed five staff members (Staff 1-Staff 5)
onsite about this complaint. Staff 1 worked for the agency, 11 years
on and off, Staff 2 three months, Staff 3 one year, Staff 4 and Staff 5
almost six years respectively.
All five employees reported being paid by the agency via check
every two weeks. These employees did not report concerns with not
being paid timely; nor did they have a missed or bounced paycheck.
None of the staff were aware of caregivers not being paid or not
being paid timely. Staff 5 reported the agency has not had any recent
problem in this area. She said the only issues that come into play at
times relates to DOCs (Difficulties of care) payment issues and CA
has worked with those families to give them advance payments while
all is worked out with the department. She reported feeling the
agency is in a good financial area.
Foster Parents/Caregivers:
During this special investigation I interviewed four foster parents and
four unlicensed relative caregivers either on 1/10/2025 or 1/13/2024.
• Of the eight caregivers (Caregiver A through Caregiver H)
interviewed, all reported being paid timely during the time they
have been licensed and or connected to the agency, which
ranged from under one year to three to four years. All with the
exception of one foster parent, who had not fostered in about
a year, had a child or children placed in their care by way of
the agency. All reported payment for the foster child’s care is
or was by way of a monthly check. None of these caregivers
reported any missed or bounced foster care payments. All
eight of the caregivers reported the agency works well with
them and they would recommend the agency to other
caregivers.
Document Review:
The financial Compliance Monitoring Memo as described and
referenced earlier in this report.
The agency’s prior 2022C0420008 special investigation report
which showed debts and obligations as indicated during that
investigation. Additionally, documents from the CA showed proof
that these debts and obligations have or are being paid:
6

The agency’s lease was made on 9/1/2021. The agency was to pay
an annual lease payment in the sum of $71,280, that was payable
monthly in the amount of $5,940. The agency’s electricity, telephone,
and gas were included in their lease payment. The agency showed
proof that those payments were being made regularly.
• The agency’s current lease is reported as $6,179.97 monthly.
Payment invoices from 1/1/2024 through 12/1/2024 and
copies of checks for each month showed a payment of $
6,179.97 monthly payment for rent to the agency’s current
landlord, P & A Development Group. Additionally, a
statement on P & A Development letterhead received on
12/19/2024 indicated the agency’s rent is paid in full until
1/1/2025.
The agency’s $150,000 Small Business Administration loan was
granted in 2020: with a thirty-year repayment in the amount of
641.00 monthly beginning July 2022.
• A copy of a transaction history from the First Independent
Bank showed a list of payments in the amount of $641.00 for
SBA loan for May, August, October, November and December
of 2024; and a $1300.00 payment in July 2024 for July and
June 2024. CA had reported the loan had been deferred until
May 2024. CA reported the September 2024 payment was
missed but was being paid with the agency’s January 2025’s
payment.
The agency had an old IRS debt which at the time of the
2022C0420008 special investigation was $957,571.66 for a tax
matter related to 6/2018, 9/2018, 12/2018, 3/2019 and 6/2019; as
well as a tax period in 2015, 2016 and 2017. The agency entered
into an installment agreement with the IRS in May 2023. The agency
agreed to pay monthly installments of $2,000.00 initially, with that
increasing overtime to $3,300.00 monthly.
• Statements received from the agency on 12/5/2024 of bank
account statements showed regular payments to the IRS in
the amount of $2,300.00 per month from October 2023
through February 2024; and then $3,300 per month from
February 2024 to November 2024. The account statement
showed that as of 12/4/2024 the agency owes the IRS
$147,607.16.
HBC was reported to have an outstanding overpayment balance
owed to MDHHS for 2014 and 2015. The amount of that debt was
originally not certain; and HBC questioned that debt. The agency’s
2023 renewal inspection report mentioned the debt, but did not list
7

an amount. A figure of $211, 297.73 was later noted as the reported
MDHHS debt. Then $265,013 was alleged in this complaint:
• The agency believed it did not owe such that large debt
amount based on information reported below.
• The agency indicated it addressed the matter of the large debt
reportedly owed MDHHS back in 2022 and 2023 and it was
not clear as to whether these monies were owed.
• HBC suggested back then that MDHHS had not provided
transparency in their accounting of the repayment amounts or
a current balance owed.
• HBC also reasoned that since MDHHS did not make
collection attempt efforts during the past few years, MDHHS
should forgive any remaining debt owed.
• HBC was to continue discussion with the Department
regarding that matter; and reported setting aside $1000 per
month to utilized, if the law required HBC to repay the debt.
Copies of check request forms, and bank deposits of canceled
checks showed the agency has been depositing $1,000.00
per month into an over payment/contingency fund account
since August 2024. This fund/this action step is one the
agency put forth in its 2023 renewal inspection corrective
action plan, which was ultimately approved on 8/21/2024. This
fund was reportedly reserved for possible future obligations to
the state.
• HBC was to continue to search out this matter to try to
ascertain whether HBC owed these monies and what actual
amount. The following was provided to show its contact
efforts with MDHHS related to what if any monies are owed by
HBC.
o A 4/26/2024 Collection-Notice-Foster Care Agency letter to
HBC that indicated the department was pursuing
overpayments that occurred since April 2014, and it was
discovered in or after July 2016. The amount indicated in
this letter was $262.65. The letter asked HBC to make the
payment.
o Copy of a cancelled check and payment recorded showed
$262.65 was paid to the State on 5/14/2024.
o A 10/27/2024 “To Whom It May Concern” letter that was
from Financial Clerk gave a recap of phone calls reportedly
to the State, from 9/27/2024-10/28/2024. A phone number
as to where the phone calls were made was not included
in this letter. This letter and the subsequent letters below
by Financial Clerk all relate to the agency’s effort to obtain
proof from the Department related to what monies may be
owed to the Department by HBC.
8

o Another letter from Financial Clerk, that was not dated,
similar to the one noted above, to the State of Michigan
naming Financial Clerk and her attempts to contact
someone on various dates. This letter indicated Financial
Clerk spoke with a gentleman on 8/29/2024 and the
person reporting the agency balance was $2477.95, that
included a check HBC sent for $992.64 on 8/27/2024 that
had not yet been received.
o Another letter similar to the one noted above dated
8/29/2024 from Finance Clerk with basically the same
information listed. This letter referenced check payments
of $992.64; $743.00 due 9/18/2024; and $742.31 due
10/18/24; which total the $2477.95 previously stated.
o The agency provided proof the $ 2477.95 was paid by way
of checks for $743.00 dated 9/16/2024. $742.31 dated
10/16/2024; and $ 992.64 dated 8/27/2024. All three of
these payments together total the $ $2477.95.
o A 10/10/2024 letter from MDHHS (Bureau of Finance &
Accounting- Reconciliation and Dispute Unit-MM) to HBC
that indicated in response to the letter received from HBC
requesting a total balance due MDHHS for foster care over
payment, the Department agreed that what was stated in
the agency’s letter of $742.31 being the amount that was
owed as the only balance the agency is to repay related.
The $ 742.31 was for Accounts Receivable (AR) Claim #
202309114578. The agency showed proof of this payment
by check on 10/16/2024, as referenced above.
Since the above was reported by the agency related to the
overpayment balance owed the state of Michigan; and since the
original completion of this report on 1/14/2025, I had follow-up
contact with the MDHHS- Compliance Monitoring Unit and HBC.
MDHHS-Compliance Monitoring Unit Staff
I met with Senior Auditor, (referenced earlier in this report) his
supervisor, Financial Compliance Manager, and Second Auditor via
TEAMs on 3/11/2025. Senior Auditor reported he had written a
financial concern memo for the agency every year since 2019. He
reported in November 2024, he completed the Memo of Concern
(which resulted in this special investigation). He reported when the
agency filed its 2023 independent financial audit report, the agency
did not include a management letter. He reported although the
absence of a management letter does not necessarily mean or imply
anything negative, a management letter is usually included with the
financial audit. Senior Auditor reported the overpayment owed by
HBC to MDHHS is now seen as a long-term liability. He and Second
9

Auditor reported some type of notification would have been provided
to the agency by MDHHS in the past related to these outstanding
MDHHS overpayments.
Financial Compliance Manager reported typically if an agency has
outstanding funds owed to MDHHS, the matter will go to collections,
and there is no specific timeframe for that to occur. She reported not
being able to speculate as to why HBC’s specific overpayment
matter might not have gone further into collections. She reported, if
an agency is trying to pay back funds, her department will get that
agency to the right department. She reported to her knowledge, no
one from HBC reached out to her department to ask about this
overpayment debt.
On 3/11/2025, and 3/13/2025 via email Senior Auditor provided me
various financial documents which consisted of:
o A “Collection Notice-Foster Agencies” letter to HBC dated
9/12/2018. This letter indicated MDHHS was pursuing
overpayments that occurred in April 2014 and discovered in
or after July 2016. The letter indicated that the overpayment
process would be ongoing to collect all identified
overpayments, even for older services dates and that the
agency would be liable for all overpayments until repayment
is made. This letter indicated the total overpayment at that
time was $123,787.36.
o “A Total Recoupment Amount” spreadsheet document for
HBC for various warrant payment amounts ranging from
2014 to 2017. The total amount noted as owed by the
agency on this spreadsheet document was $123,787.36.
o An undated Outstanding Balance Accounting document, for
“initial advance payments” on 12/8/2014 and “push advance
payments” on 4/21/2015. This document showed in 2014,
$161,297.73 was the initial over payments to the agency;
and HBC made monthly payments to the department on that
debt until October 2022. The agency’s monthly payments
had ranged from $5,000.00 to $15,069.06 and a total of
$70,000.00 was paid toward that $161,297.73. A balance of
$91,297.73 was left. This document also showed
$120,000.00 was owed by the agency for overpayments in
2015, and no payments had been received from the agency.
The $91,297.73 balance coupled with the $120,000.00
balance showed the agency’s owed $211,297.73 for
overpayments at that time.
o A copy of an email dated 10/30/2024 from Senior Auditor to
the Foster Care Guardianship and Adoption Division Director
that indicated information similarly to the 11/22/2024
10

Concern Memo and noted concern with the agency due to its
high debts.
o A copy of a 3/10/2023 emails chain, initially one from Prior
Financial Compliance Auditor to other DHHS staff that
indicated regarding HBC’s debt, it looked like they owed
MDHHS $364,000.00. Then an email from the prior DCWL
Director. That email showed the Outstanding Balance
Accounting document with the overpayments amounts to the
agency, repayment amounts by the agency; and indicated
the previously mentioned $211,297.73 balance as owed by
the agency at that time.
o A copy of a 11/22/2024 Memo, to the Foster Care,
Guardianship and Adoption Division Director, which was the
memo that generated this special investigation. It indicated a
debt for the agency of a long-term liability payable to
MDHHS for $265,013.00.
What is gleamed from this information is that the debt owed by the
agency to the department ranges between $ 211,297.73 and
$364,000.00.
On 5/06/2025 the Financial Compliance Manager replied to an
inquiry about the details outlined in this report and responded that it
appears to capture everything accurately. When asked about their
financial standing and progress made since being placed on the
current second provisional license, she replied on 5/13/2025 stating,
“It looks like there was only one issue related to them negotiating the
terms of their lease, so if they have that settled then there were no
other financial concerns noted in the audit”.
Chief Administrator (CA) follow up contact:
I had a follow-up meeting with HBC’s CA onsite on 3/31/2025 related
to the MDHHS overpayment amounts. I asked her about the
management letter in connection with the agency’s prior independent
financial audit as mentioned by Senior Auditor. I showed CA various
documents, I had received, specially, the Collection Notice-Foster
Agencies letter dated 9/12/2018, the Total Recoupment Amount
spreadsheet document and the undated Outstanding Balance
Accounting document. CA acknowledged receipt of the 2018 letter
and was familiar with the warrant documents but did not recall
receipt of other documents. With respect to the management letter,
CA reported all financial auditors do not complete a management
letter. She reported HBC’s prior financial auditor did not write one.
She said he gave an opinion and did not think a management letter
was important at that time. She reported HBC no longer uses that
11

financial auditor, but had the management letter been requested she
could have obtained one.
As for the over payment matter CA reported that in 2014 and 2015
due to the department reporting that agencies may not have been
being paid correctly or timely for children in care, the department
implemented a “push payment thing”. She acknowledged the
agency received various overpayments during that time. She
indicated HBC should not owe the $211,297.73 or $265,013.00
mentioned in the reports; that an amount of $152,800.06 which
shown in one area of the Outstanding Balance Accounting document
may be more accurate. She admitted the agency had made a
number of past payments toward those overpayments. She reported
the agency likely stopped paying during a time that it was struggling
to maintain. She indicated with this all being over 10 years ago, she
cannot recall all aspects of the indication from the department. She
reported given that the department was not actively pursuing
repayment HBC’s previous legal counsel (who was to have been
investigating this matter for the agency with respect to the agency’s
prior corrective plan), had advised contesting this matter and
questioned if the overpayment matter could be waivered. CA
reported she never denied that the agency might owe a larger back
payment to MDHHS, and that was/is why the agency has been
putting aside the $1000, per month. She reported she only
questioned the amount; and that in their/ Finance Clerk’s recent
exploration of what is owed, hundreds of thousands of dollars were
not being indicated. CA admitted she/HBC had not contacted the
MDHHS Compliance Monitoring unit. She reported she would do so.
I provided her with the Financial Compliance Manager’s name and
number. CA reported the agency is only interested in working out a
payment plan with MDHHS. She reported HBC would be able to pay;
as it has previously paid up to $10,000. 00 per month.
On 4/1/2025 CA emailed me and indicated she made contact with
Financial Compliance Manager and information was pending to her.
She indicated HBC intention is to enter into a repayment agreement
as quickly as possible.
Documents provided by CA prior showed proof that the agency is
current on it debits and obligations and better financial standing
A 12/18/2024 statement from First Independence Bank of which
holds the agency’s business account.
• The statement showed the agency’s current balance as
$132,371.53, with a year-to-date average current balance of
$90,212.13.
12

Foster care payments to caregiver from January 2024 to October
2024
• Showing regular payments to caregivers.
Copy of 2024 Annual Budget which showed:
• The agency projected an operating budget of $1,325,000, of
which $766.321.00 is for compensation, salaries and fringe
benefits; and $365,850.00 for board in care payments
($365,000) and assistance to individuals ($850) is the
agency’s largest expenditure.
• The agency’s total expenses as $1,316,621 with a revenue
more than $8,379.
Statement from the state showing:
• The agency is receiving payment for 38 children currently in
care, in the amount of $46,000 bi-weekly.
Analysis The evidence showed the agency continues to have financial
liabilities, and large debts in some specific areas, which includes
funds owed to MDHHS for overpayments. The evidence also shows
the agency is managing debts and paying its debtors timely.
Additionally, it showed the agency has been putting aside funds to
utilize toward repayment to MDHHS, when and if an overpayment
agreement is established. Only through additional time, and with
increased revenue may it be proven that the agency’s financial
progress will or will not continue.
Conclusion VIOLATION NOT ESTABLISHED
13

IV. RECOMMENDATION
The recommendation is to return the agency’s license from a second provisional
license to a regular license.
May 15, 2025.
